Legal Aid Bureau
expands reform efforts
By RICHARD BLAND
In recent years the Legal Aid
Bureau of Baltimore has rapidly
expanded its efforts to represent
the city's poor in court free of
charge, and reform local laws.
Located in eight neighborhood
offices, the Legal Aid Bureau
offers services primarily designed
for civil law cases.
Family troubles such as
divorce and annulment,
separation, and nonsupport
accounted for a substantial
portion of requests for assistance,
as did civil misdemeanors and
other criminal charges.
Other key areas where the
poor have sought the protection
of the Legal Aid Bureau have
been those of landlord-tenant
relations, sales contracts,
consumer and employment
disputes, state and local welfare
and prison assistance.
Many Cases
Joseph A. Matera, Executive
Director of the Baltimore Legal
Aid Bureau, observed that most
poor people never attempted to
seek court proceedings, even in
the many cases where they have
clear grounds for complaint.
"The poor don't trust the
law," Matera maintained. "The
law always seems to be taking
things away from them," he
added, "like a refrigerator for
instance." The number of
neighborhood law offices grew
from four to eight in the wake of
the 1968 riots, and although this

further localization of the Legal
Aid made it more convenient for
the poor to seek assistance there
is still a situation where only a
small percentage of the poor who
actually need or deserve legal
help actually seek it.
The Legal Aid Bureau never
turns away a poor person who
comes to them for help,
according to Matera. In recent
years the majority of individual
problems have involved
consultation and advice, while of
the cases that actually go to'
court only 10% are lost, on the
average, every year.
Struck Down
Reform of the law and the
legal system has become an
increasingly important function
of the Legal Aid Bureau. Two
years ago the Bureau resolved in
its favour the case of Long, et al
V. State of Maryland, et al in the
United States District Court for
the District of Maryland. In this
instance the Federal Court struck
down the law which had alloweu
sixteen and seventeen year-old
children in Baltimore City to be
treated as adults, rather than
juveniles.
Other recent decisions
successfully defended by the
Legal Aid Bureau have involved
the reinstatement of children in
high school who were unjustly
suspended, the reform of housing
code violations, the reform of
welfare law and consumer
protection for the poor.

Although the recent wave of rape attempts on
campus has been met with prompt University moves to
tighten security, the problem of protecting members
of the Hopkins community from crime is far from
solved.
As one administrator remarked, "It's security for
the 1920's and not for 1972." Insufficient lighting,
neglected patrolling and cursory training have
combined to make Hopkins a dangerous place to be,
especially late at night. Worse is the fact that one
guard assigned to patrol the walkway from the
athletic center to the dorms every 15 minutes, failed
even to see that the temporary lights were off for half
an hour. While it is true that the University has acted
promptly to upgrade security, combining negligent
patrolling with a student escort service that may be
ignored amounts to whistling in the dark on the part
of the University.
It will take time to see if a satisfactory security
system can be worked out for this campus without
creating the atmosphere of an armed camp. In a matter
as important as security, no quick and easy solutions
should be expected. But at the same time, no
satisfactory solution will be found unless everyone
concerned cooperates to assure the safety of
themselves and of others around them.

Legal Aid Bureau
expands reform efforts
By RICHARD BLAND
In recent years the Legal Aid
Bureau of Baltimore has rapidly
expanded its efforts to represent
the city's poor in court free of
charge, and reform local laws.
Located in eight neighborhood
offices, the Legal Aid Bureau
offers services primarily designed
for civil law cases.
Family troubles such as
divorce and annulment,
separation, and nonsupport
accounted for a substantial
portion of requests for assistance,
as did civil misdemeanors and
other criminal charges.
Other key areas where the
poor have sought the protection
of the Legal Aid Bureau have
been those of landlord-tenant
relations, sales contracts,
consumer and employment
disputes, state and local welfare
and prison assistance.
Many Cases
Joseph A. Matera, Executive
Director of the Baltimore Legal
Aid Bureau, observed that most
poor people never attempted to
seek court proceedings, even in
the many cases where they have
clear grounds for complaint.
"The poor don't trust the
law," Matera maintained. "The
law always seems to be taking
things away from them," he
added, "like a refrigerator for
instance." The number of
neighborhood law offices grew
from four to eight in the wake of
the 1968 riots, and although this

further localization of the Legal
Aid made it more convenient for
the poor to seek assistance there
is still a situation where only a
small percentage of the poor who
actually need or deserve legal
help actually seek it.
The Legal Aid Bureau never
turns away a poor person who
comes to them for help,
according to Matera. In recent
years the majority of individual
problems have involved
consultation and advice, while of
the cases that actually go to'
court only 10% are lost, on the
average, every year.
Struck Down
Reform of the law and the
legal system has become an
increasingly important function
of the Legal Aid Bureau. Two
years ago the Bureau resolved in
its favour the case of Long, et al
V. State of Maryland, et al in the
United States District Court for
the District of Maryland. In this
instance the Federal Court struck
down the law which had alloweu
sixteen and seventeen year-old
children in Baltimore City to be
treated as adults, rather than
juveniles.
Other recent decisions
successfully defended by the
Legal Aid Bureau have involved
the reinstatement of children in
high school who were unjustly
suspended, the reform of housing
code violations, the reform of
welfare law and consumer
protection for the poor.

By NILS BRUBAKER
Those who attended last
week's home football game
against F&M may have noticed a
handful of dignified old
gentlemen seated in the second
row, just west of the exit ramp
beneath the press box. Probably
two of the spectators were
recognized quite easily: Dean

Director David Kauffman. The

man whom lacrosse Coach Bob
Scott has called "one of the most
outstanding athletes in Hopkins
history." His name? C. Gardner
Mallonee.
Gardner Mallonee (or Gard, or
Mal, or Mr. Mal) played football
and lacrosse for the University
during the years 1924-1928. He
played as an end on the varsity
football team for four years, was
the varsity captain as a junior and

senior, receiving All-Maryland
honors those two years, and was
given a major college
All-American honorable mention
by the New York Sun his senior
year. He played defense for the
lacrosse squad for three years,
making second team
All-American as a junior, first
team All-American as a senior,
and leading the Johns Hopkins
US Olympic lacrosse team to
Amsterdam in 1928.*
After sraduation, he

In 1946, after having also served

collegiate referee until a severe
stroke in 1960 debilitated him.

elected to the Lacrosse

Kaline and Jim Lacey.

throughout. Scattered atop the
furniture and mantle are old

bric-a-brac that the Mallonees

Chairman of the Political

In 1962 an official of NBC

from 1920 to 1960 and hired

them.
There are two rifajOr ways

Cummings explained. The first is
the mechanical method; a
computer is fed a mathematical
model containing the results of

guesses made by Cummings and
his associates on the results of
the upcoming election. As the

actual vote count is fed into the
computer and through the math
model it corrects the educated
guesses and begins to show the
swing of the election. In this way

range of available seats in the
House that can go Republican or
Democratic and what probably
will happen there.
The second way involves
human prediction and a figure
called the House Basic Listing

of states in alphabetical order,

District, and what percentage of •
seats that went Republican and

election are fed into a computer

board.
